Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current through a plough (U.S. "plow") accessed through a narrow slot in the road. In the United States, much (though not all) of the former streetcar system in Washington, D.C. (discontinued in 1962) was operated in this manner to avoid the unsightly wires and poles associated with electric traction. The same was true with Manhattan's former streetcar system. The evidence of this mode of running can still be seen on the track down the slope on the northern access to the abandoned Kingsway Tramway Subway in central London, United Kingdom, where the slot between the running rails is clearly visible, and on P and Q Streets west of Wisconsin Avenue in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington DC, where the abandoned tracks have not been paved over. The slot can easily be confused with the similar looking slot for cable trams/cars

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity of name, there is no documentary evidence that Edison's phonograph was based on Scott's phonautograph. Edison first tried recording sound on a wax-impregnated paper tape, with the idea of creating a "telephone repeater" analogous to the telegraph repeater he had been working on. Although the visible results made him confident that sound could be physically recorded and reproduced, his notes do not indicate that he actually reproduced sound before his first experiment in which he used tinfoil as a recording medium several months later. The tinfoil was wrapped around a grooved metal cylinder and a sound-vibrated stylus indented the tinfoil while the cylinder was rotated. The recording could be played back immediately. The Scientific American article that introduced the tinfoil phonograph to the public mentioned Marey, Rosapelly and Barlow as well as Scott

Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again.

Reviews of the various editions of Windows 8 have been mixed. Tom Warren of The Verge said that although Windows 8's emphasis on touch computing was significant and risked alienating desktop users, a "tablet PC with Windows 8 makes an iPad feel immediately out of date" due to the capabilities of the operating system's hybrid model and increased focus on cloud services. David Pierce of The Verge described Windows 8 as "the first desktop operating system that understands what a computer is supposed to do in 2012" and praised Microsoft's "no compromise" approach and the operating system's emphasis on Internet connectivity and cloud services. Pierce also considered the Start Screen to be a "brilliant innovation for desktop computers" when compared with "folder-littered desktops on every other OS" because it allows users to interact with dynamic information. In contrast, an ExtremeTech article said it was Microsoft "flailing" and a review in PC Magazine condemned the Metro-style user interface. Some of the included apps in Windows 8

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. For

From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico

In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. Peng was convinced that the war would be protracted, and that neither side would be able to achieve victory in the near future. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. He poured gasoline on himself but police quickly surrounded him and carried him away. Two other demonstrators tried to storm the torch but failed.

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Many others like Voltaire held that without belief in a God who punishes evil, the moral order of society was undermined. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer precipitation maximum (for example, most of the Midwestern U.S.). Most heavy precipitation events in St. John's are the product of intense mid-latitude storms

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. Prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore minimize the influence of the Atlantic Ocean. The hottest month is July, with a mean temperature of 73.4

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. Constantius, summoned the bishops of the East to meet at Seleucia in Isauria, and those of the West to Rimini in Italy. A preliminary conference was held by the Arians at Sirmium, to agree a formula of faith. A "Homoeon" creed was adopted, declaring The Son to be "like the Father". The two met in autumn of 359. At Seleucia, one hundred and fifty bishops, of which one hundred and five were semi-Arian. Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the antennae of male moths can detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometers. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) is known for its wagging movements as a form of communication within the colony; it can waggle with a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging movements can signal the arrival of new material into the nest and aggression between workers can be used to stimulate others to increase foraging expeditions. There is a pronounced tendency for there to be a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile acuity, such that most insects with well-developed eyes have reduced or simple antennae, and vice versa. Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known by its initials as Bagatz בג"ץ), the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, primarily in matters regarding the legality of decisions of State authorities: Government decisions, those of local authorities and

Romantic relationships tend to increase in prevalence throughout adolescence. By age 15, 53% of adolescents have had a romantic relationship that lasted at least one month over the course of the previous 18 months. In a 2008 study conducted by YouGov for Channel 4, 20% of 14−17-year-olds surveyed revealed that they had their first sexual experience at 13 or under in the United Kingdom. A 2002 American study found that those aged 15–44 reported that the average age of first sexual intercourse was 17.0 for males and 17.3 for females. The typical duration of relationships increases throughout the teenage years as well. This constant increase in the likelihood of a long-term relationship can be explained by sexual maturation and the development of cognitive skills necessary to maintain a romantic bond (e.g. caregiving, appropriate attachment), although these skills are not strongly developed until late adolescence. The first Sky television rights agreement was worth £304 million over five seasons. The next contract, negotiated to start from the 1997–98 season, rose to £670 million over four seasons. The third contract was a £1.024 billion deal with BSkyB for the three seasons from 2001–02 to 2003–04. The league brought in £320 million from the sale of its international rights for the three-year period from 2004–05 to 2006–07. It sold the rights itself on a territory-by-territory basis. Sky's monopoly was broken from August 2006 when Setanta Sports was awarded rights to show two out of the six packages of matches available. This occurred following an insistence by the European Commission that exclusive rights should not be sold to one television company. Sky and Setanta paid a total of £1.7 billion, a two-thirds increase which took many commentators by surprise as it had been widely assumed that the value of the rights had levelled off following many years of rapid growth. A predator's effect on its prey species is hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it is seen that the population of a predator will correlationally rise and fall with the population of its prey in a cycle similar to the boom and bust cycle of economics. If a predator overhunts its prey, the prey population will lower to numbers that are too scarce for the predators to find. This will cause the predator population to dip, decreasing the predation pressure on the prey population. The decrease in predators will allow the small number of prey left to slowly increase their population to somewhere around their previous abundance, which will allow the predator population to increase in response to the greater availability of resources. If a predator hunts its prey species to numbers too low to sustain the population in the short term, they can cause not only the extinction

The other usage refers to a language that is socially subordinated to a regional or national standard language, often historically cognate or related to the standard language, but not actually derived from it. In this sense, unlike in the first usage, the standard language would not itself be considered a "dialect," as it is the dominant language in a particular state or region, whether in terms of social or political status, official status, predominance or prevalence, or all of the above. Meanwhile, the "dialects" subordinate to the standard language are generally not variations on the standard language but rather separate (but often related) languages in and of themselves. For example, most of the various regional Romance languages of Italy, often colloquially referred to as Italian "dialects," are, in fact, not actually derived from modern standard Italian, but rather evolved from Vulgar Latin separately and individually from one another and independently of standard Italian, long prior to the diffusion of a national

The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of Pakistan. In the United States, Lindlof and Taylor write, "Cultural studies [were] grounded in a pragmatic, liberal-pluralist tradition". The American version of cultural studies initially concerned itself more with understanding the subjective and appropriative side of audience reactions to, and uses of, mass culture; for example, American cultural-studies advocates wrote about the liberatory aspects of fandom.[citation needed] The distinction between American and British strands, however, has faded.[citation needed] Some researchers, especially in early British cultural studies, apply a Marxist model to the field. This strain of thinking has some influence from the Frankfurt School, but especially from the structuralist Marxism of Louis Althusser and others. The main focus of an orthodox Marxist approach concentrates on the production of meaning. Harris made several important changes to the school, reorganizing it into a true university, whereas before, its organization had remnants of the Academy days. At the beginning of his tenure, the school was not officially recognized as a university by any accreditation organization. By the end of his term, the school was accredited under all major accrediting organizations at the time. He was eventually replaced by Howard S. McDonald, who received his doctorate from the University of California. When he first received the position, the Second World War had just ended, and thousands of students were flooding into BYU. Economists Hendrik Wolff, Howard Chong and Maximilian Auffhammer discuss the HDI from the perspective of data error in the underlying health, education and income statistics used to construct the HDI. They identified three sources of data error which are due to (i) data updating, (ii) formula revisions and (iii) thresholds to classify a country’s development status and conclude that 11%, 21% and 34% of all countries can be interpreted as currently misclassified in the development bins due to the three sources of data error, respectively. The authors suggest that the United Nations should discontinue the practice of classifying countries into development bins because - they claim - the cut-off values seem arbitrary, can provide incentives for strategic behavior in reporting official statistics, and have the potential to misguide politicians, investors, charity donors and the public who use the HDI at

The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender currently coached by Bill Self. The team has won five national titles, including three NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988, and 2008. The basketball program is currently the second winningest program in college basketball history with an overall record of 2,070–806 through the 2011–12 season. The team plays at Allen Fieldhouse. Perhaps its best recognized player was Wilt Chamberlain, who played in the 1950s. Kansas has counted among its coaches Dr. James Naismith (the inventor of basketball and only coach in Kansas history to have a losing record), Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Phog Allen ("the Father of basketball coaching"), Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Roy Williams of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and Basketball Hall of Fame inductee and former NBA Champion Detroit Pistons coach Larry Brown. This received a British Patent in 1880.[dubious – discuss] On 18 December 1878, a lamp using a slender carbon rod was shown at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemical Society, and Swan gave a working demonstration at their meeting on 17 January 1879. It was also shown to 700 who attended a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on 3 February 1879. These lamps used a carbon rod from an arc lamp rather than a slender filament. Thus they had low resistance and required very large conductors to supply the necessary current, so they were not commercially practical, although they did furnish a demonstration of the possibilities of incandescent lighting with relatively high vacuum, a carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires. The morning after the election, the major candidates were neck and neck. It was clear that the result in Ohio, along with two other states who had still not declared (New Mexico and Iowa), would decide the winner. Bush had established a lead of around 130,000 votes but the Democrats pointed to provisional ballots that had yet to be counted, initially reported to number as high as 200,000. Bush had preliminary leads of less than 5% of the vote in only four states, but if Iowa, Nevada and New Mexico had all eventually gone to Kerry, a win for Bush in Ohio would have created a 269–269 tie in the Electoral College. The result of an electoral tie would cause the election to be decided in the House of Representatives with each state casting one vote, regardless of population. Such a scenario would almost certainly have resulted in a victory for Bush, as Republicans controlled more House delegations. Therefore, the outcome of the election hinged solely on the result

Nanjing ( listen; Chinese: 南京, "Southern Capital") is the city situated in the heartland of lower Yangtze River region in China, which has long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism. It is the capital city of Jiangsu province of People's Republic of China and the second largest city in East China, with a total population of 8,216,100, and legally the capital of Republic of China which lost the mainland during the civil war. The city whose name means "Southern Capital" has a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, having served as the capitals of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century AD to 1949. Other historians find incongruity in the proposition that the very place where the vast number of the scholars that influenced the scientific revolution received their education should also be the place that inhibits their research and the advancement of science. In fact, more than 80% of the European scientists between 1450–1650 included in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography were university trained, of which approximately 45% held university posts. It was the case that the academic foundations remaining from the Middle Ages were stable, and they did provide for an environment that fostered considerable growth and development. There was considerable reluctance on the part of universities to relinquish the symmetry and comprehensiveness provided by the Aristotelian system, which was effective as a coherent system for understanding and interpreting the world. However, university professors still utilized some autonomy, at least in the sciences, to choose epistemological foundations and methods. Israel has a school life expectancy of 15.5 years and a literacy rate of 97.1% according to the United Nations. The State Education Law, passed in 1953, established five types of schools: state secular, state religious, ultra orthodox, communal settlement schools, and Arab schools. The public secular is the largest school group, and is attended by the majority of Jewish and non-Arab pupils in Israel. Most Arabs send their children to schools where Arabic is the language of instruction. Education is compulsory in Israel for children between the ages of three and eighteen. Schooling is divided into three tiers – primary school (grades 1–6), middle school (grades 7–9), and high school (grades 10–12) – culminating with Bagrut matriculation exams. Proficiency in core subjects such as mathematics, the Hebrew language, Hebrew and general literature, the English language, history, Biblical scripture and civics is necessary to receive a Bagrut certificate. An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the life experiences of children of the poor do not necessarily have the stereotypical consequences that most of us imagine. The poor have their own social structures based on a distinct way of communicating, a unique type of group identity, and a certain understanding of power. Poor people may view themselves as disadvantaged but they view their communities as supportive and look to their family for support. The authors of this study use their own experiences as children of the poor to examine the meaning of the life of the poor as it relates to the development of identity in adolescent males.

In order to investigate these topics, they use in-depth, naturalistic interviews with 20 adolescents of poor families who are being raised in a low-income neighborhood in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two home and two away. The exact pre-season match ups, time-slots, dates, and locations are determined by the NFL on the fourth Thursday of August every year. Pre-season games are considered a part of the regular schedule since they represent the beginning of the NFL’s regular season.

In practice, not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match. Thus, as long as there isn't a serious problem with the rules of the match, like a broken rule being applied wrongly, there won't be a disqualification because in that case the referee has a duty to disqualify that rule (as long as it is legal).

In professional wrestling, it is common to have a referee break the rules of the match and disqualify the wrestler. For example, this is often done to a wrestler attempting a low blow when it is illegal. On the other hand, a wrestler attempting a dive or a low blow on their opponent is more likely to get disqualified.

From about 1350–1450 construction activity proceeded rapidly, during that period the nave was extended and the aisled ambulatory or transepts were added.

The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 square metres of internal space.

Feng Yuan Lou (; "Field of Blossoms and Trees Palace") was the first Summer Palace in Beijing. It was built on the orders (and by the designs) of the Kangxi Emperor (reigned in 1661–1722), who built it to satisfy his passion for hunting, and it was completed around 1716.

The palace was built to imitate the Imperial Mausoleum, which was located on the shore of Hangzhou Bay, and in fact its entrance gates are the same ones used to access to the Mausoleum. It was a "palace to rival heaven". 

The design of the Summer Palace was very carefully modeled in 1717 by the well-known landscape painter Shi Zhiyong, who was also responsible for its major architectural

To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in 1717–20 and 1723–34. The Manchu banner was raised over the Qing capital Beijing and the Chinese capital was moved there permanently in 1735. Under the Ming-Qing transition, the Qing became the dominant power of China.

Under the Qing, the Qing dynasty established the first modern, permanent system of military recruitment in China. All male subjects of Qing were obliged to serve in a specific standing army, known as the Imperial Noble Guard. Qing emperors also created the first regular civil service in China and began to implement other reforms that would transform China into a modern nation-state. The Qing empire had a regular bureaucracy. From 1723 to 1727, an important attempt at modernization was made by Qianlong Emperor under the name "New Regulations". From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and John Clarke, has had a powerful impact in a number of areas of social research, including film studies, critical race and cultural studies, and gender studies. Building on their insights, other scholars have gone on to develop and deepen Hall and his colleagues' analysis of popular culture and post-colonialism, as well as his concept of "mediation": the ways in which cultural forms and their meanings operate through a variety of "mediating" media (ranging from popular, commercial print culture, to films and television). However, despite the growing importance of Hall's work (even to scholars who, unlike himself, were not particularly influenced by the British New Left in the 1960s), there have been few serious attempts at an assessment of his contribution, and even fewer attempts to develop a detailed analysis of his thought.

Libya's economy witnessed increasing privatization; although rejecting the socialist policies of nationalized industry advocated in The Green Book, government figures asserted that they were forging a path toward a mixed economy. Economic liberalization, beginning in 1995, occurred primarily via the privatization of certain industry sectors. However, following popular discontent with privatization plans and a significant drop in world oil prices that same year, the State Oil Company of Libya decided to renationalize some sectors of the economy, starting in September 1996.

In the first few years of the new government, the economy had a growth rate similar to that experienced when Qadhafi was in power. In 1989, GDP grew at an annual rate of 7%; in 1990 and 1991, GDP grew at an average rate of 8.1%. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. For example, mouse coat color ranges from white to red to brown to black (Hou et al., [@B9]; Lathrop et al., [@B12]). Among vertebrates, the pattern of hair types in birds is relatively distinct, often falling into three primary categories; down coat (hairless), bristles (feathered) and plumes (feathered). The number and distribution of plumes may be consistent in populations or highly varied across one individual or species (Lathrop and Alberts, [@B11]; Lathrop et al., [@B13], [@B12]).

Mammalian hair is present in all vertebrates, but is particularly abundant in mammals and birds. In mammals, hair is present on the external (visceral) surface, where it can function

More commonly, in cases where there are three or more parties, no one party is likely to gain power alone, and parties work with each other to win control over specific policy spaces. A set of conditions arise from this multi-party system which create conditions in which a given party may dominate the system. This domination may take the form of an "electoralist equilibrium," which assumes that both government policy and domestic economic policy are made by a coalition of parties, and each party makes commitments in exchange for coalition membership. In other words, coalition government leads to the development of power incentives and strategies for parties, both inside and outside the government, so that they are each compelled to develop commitments to act in ways that further their own power within the coalition. This is not a stable state of affairs in and of itself—other types of political system, such as a parliamentary system or pure representative democracy, will tend to be more stable in their own ways.

The implications are multiple as various research traditions are now[when?] heavily utilizing the lens of identity to examine phenomena.[citation needed] One implication of this is that the concept and the theory is used more broadly in social sciences, beyond sexuality, including identity, religion, nationality, language, and class.[5]

A number of scholars have suggested that identity is an emerging form of global knowledge. In their research, they argue that, even though the concept of identity has been applied to many different cultures and has different historical contexts, there are nevertheless common patterns that reflect certain kinds of relations that people enter into with their selves and with the world around them. This leads to the emergence of "identity knowledge" as a distinct form of knowledge, including scientific knowledge which is not necessarily true, but is useful for a certain goal or purpose.

Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond the finite and the contingent, and that we are somehow required to engage with the finite and contingent in "absolute ideal" fashion, as a condition of our own being. But he's just as certainly not a Kantian in that sense. He does, after all, take it that the Kantian demand that reason not be a slave to appearances is itself a matter of appearances, and thus ultimately a non-reasoning thing.

As I see it, the issue is this: the Kantians may accept Hegel's basic insight, but reject his attempt to square the circle that it leads to by insisting that what reason demands of us, in the name of truthfulness or authenticity or whatever, is itself a demand of a non-truthful, unreal, and ultimately untenable type. Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is objectively verifiable, with 'objective' corresponding to the idea that knowledge is necessarily public information. [5] This is in stark contrast to the subjectivist picture that would deny any notion of epistemic authority above the level of individual beliefs. [5] Popper holds that science is necessarily a process of gradual cumulatively acquiring knowledge, [6] while being wary of those who would hold that it is either inevitable or can be fully explained by a simple linear 'progression of thought' in which the truth is discovered bit by bit. [7] Popper's view might be described by saying that 'truth' is an external-phenomenal attribute, one belonging to the realm of 'what is', and that to be true is to be able to'make sense' of a statement. Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model for most of the colonies. The executive, legislative, and judicial powers were all united in one and the same person, the sovereign. According to Lord Mansfield: "The king was, by the law of England, the source of their whole power. He could create any office, and him they might refuse the power to create it; but, if they did, it would be annihilated by him to whom they had denied it." In practice, this meant that the king used his prerogative to appoint officers, and that the judiciary had to follow its prerogative (which often meant following the King's lead) if they were to work. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea started to split into several continents including Laurasia to the north, and Gondwana to the south ([Supplementary Fig. 1a](#SD1){ref-type="supplementary-material"}). The Gondwanan supercontinent consisted mainly of ancient ocean basins. According to a recent hypothesis^[@R3]^, the Gondwanan supercontinent formed around 290--268 Ma. During this period, India separated from the landmass by rift volcanism, and spread toward the west and north to form the Indian plate ([Supplementary Fig. 1a](#SD1){ref-type="supplementary-material"}). Many ground crew at the airport work at the aircraft. A tow tractor pulls the aircraft to one of the airbridges, The ground power unit is powered by one or two large gas powered generators that are connected to the engines of the aircraft. The APUs can be used on their own to power several pieces of onboard equipment, or be used in conjunction with the main engines to power up the aircraft. As the term implies, Ground Power Unit (GPU) is a device (e.g., ground power or APU) that enables aircraft to be powered on the ground, but are not required to be connected to aircraft main engines or for that matter, even to any form of power. For example, the GPU may be connected to only the main landing gear brake system and the aircraft's APU can power another system such as the cabin's cabin lighting system.

This article describes the history of the buildings and grounds of the tower, which date back some 2,500 years, before which the entire area surrounding the tower belonged to the Jewish temple or “Second Temple” period.

Around the 7th century BC, the first Greek colonies were founded by Corinthians and Phocaeans, who were in search of colonies.

In the following century (387 BC), Tarcísio, King of Syracuse, invited Greek settlers to inhabit this area after having expelled the natives. The natives were, however, able to resist the arrival of the Greek colonists: they were defeated during the Battle of Heraclea in 387. During these centuries, and in fact until the 5th century BC, the natives resisted their new conquerors and in 390 BC they expelled them from the area.

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of egocentrism, which occur when people's actions and desires are based on their own beliefs and judgments, autistic features do not affect interactions with the people. Egocentrism in autism, which has a typical-brain structure, is typically a behavior of an autism spectrum condition.[@CIT1] Egoism is commonly considered egoistic behavior. Thus, for individuals in the autistic spectrum condition, the term egoism would be appropriate.[@CIT2] As egocentricity increases among adolescents, egocentrism plays an important role in adolescents' identity formation, ego development, and self-esteem.[@CIT3][@CIT4] Thus, it is important to recognize the factors influencing this tendency.

Hong Taiji's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese, including many newly surrendered Ming officials. The Manchus' continued dominance was ensured by an elaborate system for selecting new officials that favored the Manchu nobility. To increase his power in the provinces, Hong Taiji encouraged officials in the central government to make their sons and relatives provincial governors and he also created or supported a large bureaucracy to advise him in the provinces. This network of officials included thousands of Manchus and Han Chinese, some of them Han bannermen or non-Han Chinese "sons of heroes". The Han bannermen and the sons of heroes comprised about 40% of Hong Taiji's official corps. The Manchu officials who had assisted the Hongzhi Emperor in conquering China, and who held positions of importance in his government under the Hongzhi Emperor, now regained their former stature in the government of the Manchu state. The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic distinction within Bermudians between Afro-Bermudians, Indo-Bermudians, and 'Caucasoid' Bermudians and this obscures the historic relationships of these groups. To determine the true ancestral origins of today's Bermudians, the proportion of African, American Indian, Indo-Eurasian, and 'Caucasoid' ancestry were estimated, and compared with data on genealogical ancestry in the national census over that time period.

In addition, the genetic population stratification was examined using principal components analysis. We found that the genetic stratification in the present-day Bermuda population closely relates to the ethnic self-declared ancestry distribution.

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as urates of uric acid (UA). Birds are quite different from mammals in their biology, but also in their kidney anatomy. Birds have well-developed and lobular kidneys ([Figure 1](#pbio-0020101-g001){ref-type="fig"}A). Both kidneys extract and process urine, but each of them does so independently. However, the functions of the lobular kidney have not been well defined. Traditionally, these functions were assumed to be related to excretion of UA, but the fact that UA must be removed by a uricotelic mechanism had prevented studies of the metabolic activity of the lobular kidneys. Consequently, the precise physiological functions of the lobular kidney remained largely undefined.

The Guangxu Emperor died on November 14, 1908, and on November 15, 1908, Cixi also died. Rumors held that she killed herself out of grief, and the Japanese also did not take long to arrive at the conclusion that she was responsible for his death and that she was "a very dangerous person." During the 1930s, the first two motorways were built across the Land, the A4 motorway as an important east-west connection in central Germany and the A5 as part of the planned German autobahn system. The first autobahn, the Reichsautobahn 1, was built between Berlin and Munich by 1942.

After World War II, Germany’s postwar road system was essentially as it was before, and the autobahns were the main transport arteries.

Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, privilege and precedence.

Priests were bound to their collegia by a promise called the juramentum in perpetuo or juramentum in perpetuum, whereby they vowed to uphold Catholic practice and doctrine. For the reformers, papal absolutism was their greatest obstacle, and a papist clergy was intolerable.

Bishops were elected by the people, then held by the collegiata, a requirement that the Roman Senate had decreed in 474 Bce. The appointment of bishops was vested in the people (populus) and, by custom, the college of cardinal priests. This requirement had already been superseded by the emperor’s imperial collegia.

When Nintendo released the NES in the US, the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those that preceded it and they believed that the NES's design would help achieve this goal.

The North American NES was released in July 1985, and by the end of October, 2.5 million units were sold.[1] The success of the NES in the US brought a big change in the Japanese console market for the following years. Whereas the Japanese Super Famicom and other Japanese systems had been dominating the market since the 1980s, the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES) took almost the entire share as of 1993.

As of January 6, 2009, the NES has sold over 110 million units worldwide, which makes it the third-highest-selling console of all time (behind the Nintendo GameCube and the Wii). [2]

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the title is held up above the entrance, the challenger is forced to jump up and grab hold one rung higher, and the champion is not allowed to touch the floor. It can be extended if the champion grabs a hold of the ladder. If the champion is able to climb to the top, they retain, and so on. This is similar to the original ladder match in which the original ladder champions were not allowed to break or cut the ladders, instead being forced to climb, only to be then made their by climbing down. These matches are usually won as a result of outside interference, usually involving weapons, as a referee must make sure the match is not finished in some way. American comic books have adopted the character type for stories of their own like the mutant-villain Silver Samurai of Marvel Comics. The design of this character type can have far-reaching effects in the world around us. They are usually played-up and exaggerated in order to fit the needs of the story. This results in a character type that is, in reality, very little more than a cartoon.

In a way, the real character of the Superman archetype appears to be in conflict with the modern era of the character. The character is often referred to as an “American hero” – the sort of character who comes to the aid of a member of the public against, say, a gang of robbers. Superman’s entire backstory is not based in his being a real person. His backstory is based in being brought “back into the present”. The story of Superman is not an individual’s story, but an action of the entire world.

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, a true predator does not eat its prey. True predators do not feed on the prey at all. Instead, they feed on the nutrients of the prey, namely nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium found in their tissues. True predators are not typically food chains, since the food chain implies the food as the prey.
The true predators in the animal kingdom, on land and in the sea, prey mainly on smaller, land-based or sea-based, animals. Some true predators may be seen to also prey on other plants. These true predators then turn the plant into "nutrient-rich food for the animal"

True predators can be classified into 2 categories, primary and secondary. Primary true predators do not feed on their prey at all. Instead, their prey's flesh, blood, etc., provides the nutrients they need. Secondary true predators

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary Luis Ramirez Herrera, ended the war between the United States and Mexico, which began on November 8, 1846.

Following the United States victory and the signing of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hill on February 2, 1848, both parties moved towards reconciliation. The result was the Treaty of Tlatelolco which came into effect on September 9, 1848, allowing the return of people and property that had been taken by the war. The original signatories included President James K. Polk and ex-president and Mexican ambassador to the United States Manuel de la Peña y Peña, who represented the United States, while Ramirez Herrera represented Mexico.

In the 16th century, the Portuguese colonization of Brazil prompted the rise of a new kind of city, the Vila, characterized by an absence of walls and the existence of defensive towers. Its inhabitants were mainly craftsmen, artisans and slaves.

Brazil remained under Portuguese and Spanish rule until 1822, when it was granted independence by Napoleon.

By 1826, it had gained the status of Republic, and in 1889 was recognized as a United States province. In 1953 Brazil became a Federative Republic (similar to state, state-federal, or confederation), and in 1988 the Congress voted to adopt the current name as the Federation of Brazil.

Terry Eastland, the author who wrote From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice states, "Most arguments for affirmative action fall short because they don't include a clear account of how human beings came to have so much variation in their mental abilities." Eastland's argument was that the existence of "racial minorities with genetic advantages" in the human population was "a direct result of evolutionary pressure." Eastland's book argued that racial differences in mental ability "are natural," and that racial quotas and preferences "are unnatural, unfair and unjust." Many conservatives have been receptive to Eastland's arguments because he takes a "Darwinian" point of view, one in which people and other animals, including human beings, did not become "different" but gradually evolved.

The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, an invitation is sent to the Duke of Cambridge for what will be the final audience before the heir to the throne formally ascends the throne. The Duke wears a purple military uniform, and the monarch is attended by the entire Cabinet and a small, ceremonial Royal Household following the royal train. The Duke is formally welcomed in the East Room, with the King, the Prime Minister, and other leading members of the Royal Family standing alongside him to escort him into the Senate Chamber. Members of the royal family are not barred from the chamber, nor from the balcony on the south side, where the Duke has an audience with the House; the Duke, however, only stays for a short while and returns to Parliament. The Chamber is the site of a number of important events over the life of the monarch, including the investiture of the Order of the Garter

The early and mid-1980s saw economic trouble for Libya; from 1982 to 1986, the country's annual oil revenues dropped from $21 billion to less than $1 billion, equivalent to little more than one-third of current state revenues. In the late 1980s, after having unsuccessfully tried to attract foreign investment — which mostly came with political conditions attached — Libya initiated a series of radical economic reforms. The reforms resulted in the introduction of the "structural adjustment program" of the World Bank Group, which would later become the blueprint for austerity economics.

In 1980, just nine years after the "Arabization" of government departments and the "nationalization" of almost 50% of the economy, Libya embarked on a process of decentralization of government, which would eventually result in a system whereby central government authority could be exercised through the state-owned companies. Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus two digital audio tracks; and Dolby was first used for both analog and digital audio. (Digital audio would be standard for the Dolby Digital format.) Video would likely be stored on a separate track or even a different disc than the audio, and in an older version of the standard a separate analog VBI (Vertical Blanking Interval) was also used to store data about the video.

There would be no need to compress the audio or video files like there is today, as CDs could hold about 25 times as much digital information as one of the Blu-ray Discs. But compression was added to CD to make room for the larger discs, so it is likely that audio and video compression would exist as well, just like with the DVD's. From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles. This is known as “spin foam." The idea has been popularized by Lenny Susskind in his book, The Elegant Universe. I’ve explained it well in many publications.

Feynman’s work is a good example of what I call a “dynamically deterministic” theory of spacetime. That is, the equations of motion of a theory are derivable from the very fact that those equations describe a physically realized process.

In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy. John called on Count Philip of Flanders to contribute a number of men to his army; Flanders was allied to Léon of England, and John had persuaded the latter to provide him an army of archers and men-at-arms. John met Flemish soldiers at Pont-Audemer in October and the two sides marched together into the Norman capital. The English arrived at Gaillard just before the French were due to break off, but the defenders were willing to surrender. In return, John gave them safe conduct to the English-held city of Rouen. John was said to have taken pleasure in the destruction wrought by the sack, and he allowed only one of the city's five churches to be left standing as a memorial: the Church of St Clement, close to where now stands St Jacques church. The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and the concept is defined as the set of perceptions and beliefs one has about oneself, one's identity and one's life goals (McClelland and Dodge, [@B36]; Roberts and Jackson, [@B42]; Seligman et al., [@B33]). A high self-concept is one's subjective perception of the extent to which he has met his or her expectations of oneself (Seligman et al., [@B33]): people with a positive self-concept perceive that they have done better than is expected, which can help them to have greater mastery experiences, self-efficacy and success at school, college, adulthood, and the workplace. For its complete North American release, the Nintendo Entertainment System was progressively released over the ensuing years in four different bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the System 16, and the Super Famicom System.

A period of division for the Liberals followed, with former Treasurer John Howard competing with former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock for supremacy. The Australian economy was booming. New tax legislation was passed by the Parliament, which Howard described as a "great achievement". The Howard government was a major supporter of international trade and investment agreement, signed by Australia, Japan and other economies. Howard's policies, in part, had also established and protected a strong and vibrant non-government educational institution sector. He had also helped the public sector reduce debt. Howard led in the polls until the leadership spill of June 1999, when his deputy, Alexander Downer, led the government by 4.2 per cent. Howard suffered a serious heart attack and announced his retirement as leader.

The leadership change of June 1999 produced a change in the character of the party, from a relatively homogeneous "Howard Party", to a more diverse group of MPs with various political backgrounds. Peacock resigned as Treasurer and was appointed Foreign Minister

The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before statehood was granted to the territory on January 26, 1889. A small number of schools were in existence at that time, and the next decade saw the number of schools increase, although the territory had little industry. By the 1890s, large-scale ranching had begun, creating the need for public schools; a third of schools in the state today are schools of the territorial era, the majority of them serving grades 1-12.

As the number of pupils in the schools grew, a movement for consolidation first arose, then became well established in the early 20th century. When John's elder brother Richard became king in September 1189, he had already declared his intention of joining the Third Crusade. Richard set about raising the money necessary and then in July 1190, he left England and by the autumn met up with his allies at Tarsus. From 1189 to 1190, Henry II had been trying to keep Richard busy with the affairs of Aquitaine. However, Richard's attention was now focused elsewhere.

The Siege and Fall of Acre

Richard and his allies sailed from Tarsus in early August 1190 and landed in Palestine at dawn on 3 September 1190. They took several towns on their way to Acre and finally on 8 September they lay siege to the city, which was now under the control of Saladin. From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of Kannauj, the Hindu Pala dynasty of Bengal, and the Chudasama dynasty of Gujarat. When the last of these was overthrown by the invading Afghans, Gurjara rule extended from Multan to Dehli, and their descendants ruled as the Prathihara dynasty for centuries.[1] The dynasty is sometimes also called the "Pillai Dynasty" after Param Pala I, a great-grandson of king Brihadityagupta.[2]

The first members of the dynasty were from the Gurjaras of Kannauj. They conquered the region including Kannauj. Brihadityagupta and his grandson Vigraharaja II built a great city named Somapura or Somnagar, with the walls of which it was for a long time considered impregnable

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez (c1450-1521) and Claudio Monteverdi (1567-1643) providing impetus. In England, William Byrd (1540-1623) was probably the earliest composer of the style, but the first to win widespread renown for his work was Orlando di Lasso (c1530-1594), whose numerous works include two settings of the Magnificat.

The first Englishman to be associated with the style was John Dowland (1563-1626) who was widely regarded as the premier English lutenist of the period. He wrote settings of the Magnificat and Ave Maria in the manner of Monteverdi as well as settings of lute and keyboard. These compositions provided the initial groundwork for the a cappella English church style which then spread to Scotland and to France.

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe lay in ruins as the new Soviet Union and Nazi Germany fought to expand their influence and domination over the eastern section of the continent. There was hope for the future that the peace that ended the first world war could be a lasting one. The war in the Middle East had dragged the region into one of the most brutal conflicts in the history of mankind, and the seeds of what became the Palestine conflict had been sown then.

Since the defeat of the Nazis in July 1945, the new United Nations had been set up to manage the aftermath of the conflict, and the British government accepted it as the new order of the day. On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed. All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged. Many of these were in the town and its immediate hinterland. According to the official report submitted to the Home Office in London, the Clydebank Blitz claimed ‘the lives of 5 people of a total of 19 fatalities’.

On the very same day, another RAF bomber hit the small town of Wharton in Cheshire. The attack killed a father and a son along with three other members of the same family and set fire to more than 70 houses. In all, 14 people were killed, including 12 civilians, in the raid. The official figure of 19 fatalities is also too low. It was more than 100 when the fire brigade’s casualty figures were tallied up.

Clydebank and Wharton were the twin ‘children’ of the Blitz in the same, densely populated industrial town.

By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812. With Britain locked in a major war with France, Americans rallied around a pro-British party, leading to clashes between the American and British navies in the Chesapeake Bay. The War of 1812 was one of the shortest and least costly wars in U.S. history, and the main reasons for its success were the poor quality of British weapons and the poor strategy of British troops, who were defeated in detail on small battlefields at the Battle of York and the Battle of Bladensburg. The war’s importance is often overlooked when considering the era of the Napoleonic wars. However, it changed the United States. The U.S. military took a much larger role than it had with the Constitution, and many American military officers became the leaders who brought the South to the United States in 1820. Many elites returned to their home cities or relocated to other places. Others remained in Nanjing or became refugees in the north, west, northeast, or the southwest. The Jin regime established "feudal lordships" (jinshi) for well-connected clans.

Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology, which was popular and often depended on astronomy). Medieval universities established graduate programs in law and theology, and in the fourteenth century they also began to offer scientific or natural philosophy graduate programs; both theology and natural science were the first university programs in Europe. However, during the Medieval period all education was carried out in Latin, so there were no universities in any sense until the Early Modern period.

Medieval universities, like their medieval predecessors, were religious institutions connected to monastic or clerical institutions (and in all probability were largely funded by the latter). The first universities came about as universities were converted to Christian educational institutions in the early fourteenth century, and they were largely controlled by the Church. The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws. A board-only is one that is "self-governing," and therefore the board is also the only governing body and has the power to make all decisions.

Nonprofit organizations are created by individuals or groups to pursue social, religious, or cultural goals. The IRS defines a nonprofit organization as one which meets the criteria for the exemption provided by 26 U.S.C. § 501(c) - a federal provision that allows a nonprofit entity to keep its tax-exempt status. Other states also exempt certain nonprofit activities. For convenience, the term "tax-exempt" will be used, but this refers specifically to the federal tax exemption, not to the status of being exempt from state taxation.

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of apostasy—then the Congregation's Elders may request the accused to make a statement from his/her own account of the events leading up to the allegation without counsel or the presence of a lawyer. In such a case, the accusation is heard as a matter of fact by the Congregation's Elders, who decide whether the accusation is proved by sufficient evidence to warrant formal church discipline. The accused member is given the opportunity, but he/she is not obligated, to testify. The congregation's elders may also investigate the allegation as they see fit. All members of the Congregation are expected to refrain from discussing the matter with others; if one does, the matter will be investigated.

The Daily Northwestern is the main student newspaper. Established in 1881, and published on weekdays during the academic year, it is directed entirely by student staff. The newspaper operates independently from The University. All staff, from the daily editor down to the proofreader, serve on one or two committees where each member represents an interest on campus.

The Daily publishes an average of 18,000 copies daily, roughly 8,000 in print and 10,000 online. The newspaper began on a photocopied basis. Today print and online versions are fully interactive.

History

The name "Daily Chronicle or Northwestern Chronicle" first appeared in 1881. The Northwestern Chronicle was the first regularly published newspaper in Evanston and the original campus paper of the Northwestern University.  The Chronicle was established as a campus newspaper as a result of the success of newspapers such as The New York Sun and the Chicago Daily Tribune.  In fact, the Northwestern Chronicle was published in the same paper-mill

Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia is Europe's most dynamic small economy, and in recent years it has had the fastest economic growth of any European country as well as having the highest real estate and stock market valuations. The economy was hit hard and growth is on the way down a bit even as other nations are on the upswing. Economic news keeps getting worse, and the economy is only at about 8.5% for the year now -- the lowest of any country in 2008 -- and the government is looking at a large budget deficit (more on that to come).

A bit further north, Latvia is also taking a bit of a hit, as its own debt crisis has caused it to cut back on economic growth to more normal levels. The economy grew less than 2% in 2008, and the country will probably see a 5% growth rate in 2009.

Although the doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception appears only later among Latin (and particularly Frankish) theologians, it became ever more manifest to all Christians through the tenth century, as both Orthodox and Reformed Christians came to recognize Mary's exalted status over all other women. A few Roman Catholics, such as John Henry Cardinal Newman, saw Mary as a great exemplar for the Church, especially when suffering for Christ, but they stood on the wrong side of history in their view of Mary. The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", this is only partially correct: as we saw above, peoples invaded Western Europe from Africa and Asia. Instead, we should consider the establishment of new states in the face of the "barbarians". The political transformation was not instantaneous and not all changes were for the better. The result was a "political explosion": the creation of dozens of new kingdoms, states, empires, and republics in the fifth and sixth centuries. Europe descended into a maelstrom of violence and lawlessness. Only in the late sixth century did this turmoil begin to subside, but it left behind a political architecture that remains one of the most influential in the history of Europe. Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of A-level performance tables.

It took just a week for the first set of the new A-level results to be published. Of the 1,000 students at the highest performing comprehensive school, just six passed the all-important math grade B.

But it was the findings from secondary schools outside London that sent shock waves across the education establishment. One of Britain’s largest comprehensive school, in a quiet village in Shropshire, was found to have only 25 per cent of pupils at grades C or above.

The same school, which had an estimated intake of 1,400 students for its sixth form, had a total of 14 students at university.

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (mainly Spain, Italy, Portugal, Greece and Turkey) universities shared a common pattern of "socialist" and "individualist" orientation in terms of their student culture, their student councils, the curricula of their higher institutions of learning, and in particular, the teaching methodologies.

Socialist orientation
The universities in northern Europe developed as autonomous higher learning institutions, which meant that they grew up alongside the professional associations that they served, with those academic personnel who were not on the staff of the professional associations being in effect employees of the educational institutions to which they had been assigned. This pattern was not typical of the institutions of higher learning in southern Europe. In terms of their student culture, northern European universities developed into social organizations in which the students were active participants responsible for the content, design and general direction of the student culture.

The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages, mathematics, and science. After four years of debate between the faculty and the college's board of overseers, the report was adopted largely because of its eloquence and because of the prestige of its chief author, William Prescott, the professor of classics. The report is sometimes thought to be a kind of charter for American education -- and not without reason. But its arguments are, for the most part, weak. Its central argument is that it is both the duty and the interest of American colleges to teach "the dead languages." It goes on to state that students should spend no more than two years on these languages -- the minimum number of years necessary to teach them. Flexible or so-called "unbreakable" records made of unusual materials were introduced by a number of manufacturers at various times during the 78 years between the invention of the Lépine turntable in 1902 and the appearance of the 3-layer DIN 78 kHz compact disc in 1980. The "flexible" records were based on the "flexible" discs used as recording media since the late 1950s—that is, they were based on a lacquer-coated record with a plastic-like core layer and a plastic-like polymer-based plastic cover on which an in-depth and complete record coating had been deposited. One of a number of companies which had set up a system for manufacturing these "unbreakable records" was Zweiten Verlag AG, which is today known as Rote Recordings GmbH, with whom the author is familiar. These "unbreakable" discs have been used and marketed since the 1970s.
