Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A sample of an infected body site (such as sputum, fluid from a body site, or tissue) that is suspected of containing an infectious microorganism is incubated, often for some time period, in the selected growth medium. During the incubation, in many instances, growth of the specific agent occurs on one or more of a surface of a solid such as a culture medium. The solid surface can be placed on a solid support such as a microscope slide or in a liquid medium in multiple wells or vials, each vial containing a specific nutrient. Thus, in essence, microscopic examination of the solid support (or liquid medium) for a microbial colony can confirm whether or not a particular agent suspected of causing the disease is present in a sample of the infected body site.

Protestantism also spread from the German lands into France, where the Protestants were nicknamed Huguenots. Calvin continued to take an interest in the spread of his beliefs, and in 1562 sent Huguenot missionaries to Scotland. When, in 1566, he died, he was buried in the church of Saint Pierre in Geneva, with a fine monument over his grave.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence over their parents or teachers, given their age constraints. Adolescents may be able to exert greater influence, but they must be careful, because the parents and society often view them as a threat, often in a way that is unconscious and unexamined.

For the most part, adolescents in the United States have had a chance to shape themselves into adult identity. One can say, in a general sense, that the adolescent years have served to develop identity. As adolescents strive to create a secure place for their identity, they are often frustrated with their lack of control over external factors, including parents and society. They may not be able to gain more power over the situation, but they can do some more work on themselves.

In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding his seminal epistemological thought experiment by which he illustrated the difference from then-contemporary natural science as to the nature of knowledge—that is, whether we know something directly or know indirectly by inference or by a process of induction.

Locke's famous example is of a human arm (as we know, the arm) extended toward the moon with respect to astronomical distances. We have a natural inclination to infer the arm's extension farther away from the moon, but this tendency does not result from any knowledge of our own. Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert greater control over the rest of France. The Capetian kings were crowned at Paris, and the city was the center of government under the Kings and the First, Second, and Third Parliaments. With the Fourth and Fifth Parliaments the power moved to the King's residence at the Louvre. Paris changed in size, style, and function with the growing power of the crown.

This period was one marked by the building of the Royal Château of Versailles and the establishment of Paris as the seat of the monarchy. In addition, the monarchy created the Pont Neuf, the first great bridge. In 1793, the monarchy was overthrown in the start of the French Revolution, ending one era. Seattle typically receives some snowfall on an annual basis but heavy snow is rare. Average annual snowfall, as measured at Sea-Tac Airport, is 25.63 inches and has only been recorded once: in 2005 with 28.4 inches. In February 2005, the snow began two days earlier than average. Most of the snow fell on the 10th and 11th of the month. The snow continued into March, with snowfall amounts averaging 0.4 inch. The first measurable snowfall for the winter season occurred on the 10th of March. Some light snow occurred on March 14, with snowfall totals slightly less than 0.1 inch. The final spring snow occurred on the 27th of April and had snowfall amounts averaging 0.25 inch. This ended one of the shortest winters in recent history.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced new ways of thinking about the natural world. Before that time, most people—including scientists—believed that there was little difference between living things, and that all the individuals of a particular species were roughly the same. The new science of the time—which emphasized observation, prediction, and empiricism—required that any differences in animals be put down to variations in external, rather than internal, conditions. Because these external conditions are observable, and because they appear to be stable, they might be changed; the animals' difference in nature could therefore be explained and changed through intervention. For this it was necessary that some individuals should be separated into an order that could be observed systematically, and then treated differently. And for this purpose the physical characteristics of appearance and of colour—the categories of the physical order—were adopted.

After Cassander's death in 298 BCE, however, Demetrius, who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet, invaded Macedon, seized the capital of Thessaly and occupied Athens. There is usually an indication for a specific identification of an infectious agent only when such identification can aid in the treatment or prevention of the disease, or to determine the susceptibility or resistance of individuals to a specific agent. In other words, when the specific identification of an infectious agent is essential to the prevention of, or efficient treatment for, the disease. Infectious agents may need to be, for example, differentiated from non-infectious conditions, or distinguished or characterized as more or less virulent or pathogenic.
More particularly, the isolation and identification of an infectious agent can aid the physician in preventing the spread of the infection and also permit epidemiological studies to determine the distribution, source, transmission method, evolution, and susceptibility of an infectious agent. The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of his concept of manoeuvre warfare:

  1. _The offensive_ : The key of all manoeuvre is the pursuit of the enemy to bring him to the point of exhaustion. A retreat can then be effected without serious risk. The offensive strategy, by pursuing the enemy, obliges the adversary to constantly change his position, and at each of his posts he is forced to make his presence noticed, and gives him no breathing space. This is the secret of all tactics which depend on pursuit.
  2. _The decisive moment_ : All the movements that it is possible to effect before, after, or during, an engagement, must be calculated to bring to a successful issue, a battle or an operation of manoeuvre, at the least cost of force.
  3. _The concentration of forces_ : The grand combinations

Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress during his Presidency from 1801–1809. Jefferson has been called a secularist, but his private journals contained a variety of comments regarding religion. He stated that all men are created equal and religious belief should be personal – not institutionalized or required by law. He had a fundamental disagreement with the Christian conception of original sin. James Madison had been a Deist. He opposed the idea of one nation and one state. The U.S. Constitution declares that there is no religious test for public office. Madison wrote in the Federalist Papers (No. 10) that government is not free of religion or free from religious influence. Madison insisted that a government is responsible to God alone and that religious precepts and beliefs should be a part of government.

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a code of conduct for interacting with another person or class of people: people with tattoos are seen by some as being outsiders, they must learn to behave in a different way from those who don't have tattoos so as not to be perceived as having "defected". An inclusive boundary arises when a person, class of people, institution, or organization treats people who differ from them as though they are outsiders. This approach tends to result in the creation of special-interest groups where the rules for inclusivity are different to general rules of conduct outside such groups.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species evolved the ability to digest cellulose and other plants, which were more energetically favourable than flesh. Eventually they became herbivores and gained a large gut and increased metabolic rate. For some herbivores body temperature may have fallen so low that they require a hibernation bout in winter to keep warm. The ability to dig burrows and hibernate was later to be of great advantage – and survival means offspring. This means all mammals (except pangolins) have a teat.

It has taken a long time for mammals to evolve fur and an endothermic metabolism but once these two aspects appeared they were to prove highly useful. In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the first coffee houses began to appear in Saint-Germain-des-Prés. In the 19th century these spread across the city and became centres of artistic life and of the intellectual elite.

One way of eating cheaply in Paris is to go to one of the fast food restaurants and have what is known as a bistro plate, commonly consisting of a sandwich with a beer for lunchtime, or a salad for dinner, with an additional drink and dessert for dessert. The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As an integral part of the larger family structure, peers may have differentially powerful and influential influences on adolescent development than the parent-child and intimate familial relationships. Social relationships provide the context for the development of identity; thus, they are important components in adolescent development.[@b0005] There has been much research on the peer group and adolescent adjustment. Much of this work has focused on social relationships between adolescents and friends, finding that close friendships play important roles in the development of youth.[@b0005] Further, adolescent friendship networks are important for adolescents. Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so. The body relies on this endogenous production as long as adequate nutritional quantities of fats are available and used for metabolic or specialized purposes. As with all nutrients, we must obtain fats in sufficient quantity to offset our losses, including our endogenous losses, and it is assumed that fats cannot be stored with body tissues for later use.   
For the most part, fats are acquired from the diet, either ingested or otherwise absorbed, and, if we use them for energy and cannot store them for later use, we lose them through excreta (e.g., stool). Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the War Department's Legionnaires' program on June 30 1941.

The Legion was designed specifically to protect members of the U.S. armed forces, and members were required to prove that they would serve in the military before admission into the Legion. Members could not hold down civilian jobs at any time, and were barred from selling or receiving commissions on real estate. In December 1942, Congress passed the "Forbidden Zone Act" to limit the size of the Legion. In 1948, Congress passed the National Defense Act which gave the government the authority to remove or expel members of the Legion if they broke any laws and also changed the eligibility requirements to read: "who, while serving as a member of the Loyal Legion of the United States, the Marine Corps, or the Coast Guard, shall have voluntarily or involuntarily engaged in unauthorized activity."

Nanjing, one of the nation's most important cities for over a thousand years, is recognized as one of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China. Nanjing has been the home of many great people, such as Admiral Zheng He (the overseas voyager), Zhu Yuanzhang (the founder of the Ming dynasty), and the most popular, Mao Zedong, who was the general of the Chinese People's Liberation Army and the leader of the Chinese Communist revolution in the 1950s. Nowadays, Nanjing is a big and important city in eastern China, and is the central administrative government and commercial city of Jiangsu province. The city has 4 million permanent residents and 3 million temporary residents.

Nanjing is not a big city by the size, but it is an important regional center and is located at the historical core of China. The history is rich in Nanjing. There are plenty of historical temples, such as the Nine Dragon Walls, Wanshan Rock Statue and Temple

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections, or that were used to prevent disease, have a long history. A searchable library on the Internet of remedies that have passed through history has catalogued about 250 products from around the world with purported antimicrobial properties. Some are still in use today.

Many of these products are mixtures based on herbal remedies, and they contain a variety of different plant materials. Antimicrobial activity could be a property of individual components of the mixture, or it could result from synergistic interactions between separate components. The synergistic effect of an antimicrobial remedy containing multiple components would reduce or eliminate selection of resistant bacterial strains, which also means that use of these remedies against resistant bacterial strains will not lead to increased resistance in the treated population.

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped unless it is required for the referee to attend an incident.

The first half officially starts when the referee blows the whistle to signify the beginning of each period.  When a half is drawn to end, the clock is stopped for 10 seconds.

Teams
In Football League circles, a "league match" refers to a game of football played between two teams who have regular fixtures with other teams in the division they are playing in:

A "Premiership game" refers to a game of football played between two teams who have not formally agreed on a regular fixture schedule and are therefore playing in "a friendly match".

League matches and Cup games

Penn's charter allowed the free exercise of religion and for Penn to govern under his own rules (a rarity during the colonial period).

It gained its last significant territorial expansion as a tributary of the Empire of Japan. Following the signing of the Anglo-Mysore Wars of 1780–1784 and 1792–1793, the Mysore kingdom of the southern kingdom of Srirangapatna annexed the Empire's territory around Srirangapatna, then known as Srirangam[4]. Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental differences alone. It must be a result of historical change, and this is explored further. The basic principle of uniformitarianism is then applied to the case of the Cretaceous period. The theory of evolutionary stasis is considered and objections against it are answered. The evidence for change in the Cretaceous, leading to speciation of plants and animals, is then considered. The evidence consists of fossilized species which cannot be identified beyond genus or family, or even family. These are interpreted as being due to fossilization, and they have been used to support the theory despite being often badly preserved, especially from the Late Cretaceous. More detailed knowledge of the distribution of fossils in the Mesozoic has recently been produced and this has led to some refinement in the interpretation. Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the British Isles during the La Tène (c.400–50 AD) and early Roman times (c.50–400 AD). The name Britain comes from the Indo-European root ‘britt’ meaning wide (in reference to the expansive nature of the island) and the Latin word 'britannia’ meaning '(land of the) Britons’. The Celtic tribes of the British Isles were a close-knit group who were also known collectively as the ‘Celts’. As a term used by non-Celts in Ireland and Britain, Celt is not used in this context. Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage". It consists of a dull-grey or brownish-grey upperparts, with a greyish "mask". The bill may be darker. Sexes and ages are similar. The nonbreeding plumage of adult canaries is often described as "shiny", as a result of the glossy brownish iridescent scales on the head, wings, and sometimes tail, but they are actually more of a glossy red. His successor, Lord Morley, in 1909 split the new province into two more, Upper Assam and Lower Assam, leaving an ethnic and sectarian division in place. The new provinces were subdivided into Districts that became the basis of the Indian Districts. These districts were grouped into provinces that formed the basis of the Indian Provinces.

There's an ethnic and sectarian division of Assam in play here, but in the 1910s it wasn't yet as important as it would be down the line. It was also a province that had been in many hands, at least nominally, since the Mughal empire had collapsed. A succession of East India Company governors and generals and native princes had held Assam.

The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical objects and events could not be translated into statements about 'physical' properties and happenings. By that time, too, 'physical' properties and events were also obviously distinct from properties and events of a non-physical sort. Hence, it becomes plausible, at that time, to insist explicitly that all statements are about empirical fact, and so to embrace the view that, for example, all truth is what is asserted in those statements about ordinary objects and events that are true. This is a thesis that is most familiar to us today as a component of realism, and it is therefore to be expected that realists of this kind will often be tempted to accept a further thesis, the thesis that realism is the only tenable one.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be preyed upon by owls and other birds.  The prey also eat their predators, and the diet varies by the species.

Owls may hunt by sound, and many species are able to locate prey by sound alone. In owls, hunting is accompanied by rapid wing beats, which produce sound that carries and bounces off nearby obstacles. Sound is generally effective for large prey such as owls and bats because of this, and is an effective hunting technique in all types of environment where movement is limited by the terrain. Sound is also an effective method for hunting prey at night and in the absence of light, though some animals can detect movement even while sound is travelling. Some owls can see while their hearing is active, and can use this to locate prey. For example, the Eurasian eagle owl hunts while hunting in total darkness.

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse often referred to it as house music to describe the different music the club was listening to at that time. The term house music has been linked to Chicago and the house music scene, although other house music scenes have emerged internationally. Today, house music can be described as a blend of genres including electronic, hip hop, blues, soul, funk, rock and Latin. It usually incorporates beats created using drum machines and other electronic music instrumentation. House music can be played in dance halls, nightclubs, warehouses, restaurants, discotheques, bars and private parties, with DJ's being the primary figure and the music being created by the DJ.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. Its capital city and religious centre was Constantinople (modern‐day Istanbul) which became home to a growing Christian church. As Christianity spread through contact with the West, Byzantine civilisation was slowly influenced by changes that went on in the West after the fall of Rome.

The Byzantine Empire was established in 284 CE by the Emperor Diocletian, who divided the Roman Empire into two halves. Only the western half, later made up of Roman provinces and Italian city states, came under direct Roman rule and was known as the Western Roman Empire. The eastern half was governed by the Byzantine Emperor and came to be known as the Eastern Roman Empire or Byzantine Empire (I.R.E.). The two empires remained separate until the West sacked Constantinople by Germanic Emperor Theodoric in the latter half of the 5th century.

College Park is a relatively small airport,  south of Baltimore Metropolitan Airport, US. In 2007, the airport's  paved runway was the 11th shortest in the world. It served just over 6,000 general aviation traffic passengers per year.

The aviation history of College Park started with the Wright brothers who used the airport in 1909 for testing several of their flying machines. In 1913, Colonel Harry A. Hinton and his staff established a "Military-Mixed Flying School" ("Mixed-Airfield") at College Park, which operated until 1917.

The airport is served by local passenger air taxi services, and has scheduled and charter airline service.

On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for Palestine between the Mediterranean Sea and the Jordan River in the west and the River Kinneret (Sea of Galilee) and the River Jordan in the east. The plan envisaged the establishment of two states, Israel and Jordan, within the borders of Mandatory Palestine, but also for an Arab state within the borders defined by the 1949 Armistice Agreement in the West Bank, and an Arab state in Transjordan, but which would also be under British rule. Arab leaders were angered by the plan, which they felt did not take into account the situation in which many Arab cities and towns were located within the boundaries of the new state of Israel. These leaders refused to accept the armistice line, and refused to sign the Armistice Agreement in 1949.

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a revolution in France will be led to think, may we not say to have originated one in ourselves." The English Jacobins, Burke went on in a letter dated 12 August 1789, had "the most virtuous intention... to restore the rights of human nature in our own dominions." Burke made no distinction between absolute monarchy and constitutional monarchy. When Charles James Fox, in a letter of 15 October 1788, asked whether he could "enjoy the happiness of the French Revolution," Burke replied: "I wish a constitution for this country. But that I can wish, should be a wish of a friend for France."

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old [1]. Many copper items made in North America were found in Europe during the early years of colonization. This early use of copper was largely based on its excellent electrical conducting properties. It was known as an excellent conductive material prior to the development of steel and is one of only four metals capable of conducting electricity at room temperature.

Copper was known to the Greeks and Romans and is mentioned by the 2nd century BC Roman writer Pliny. A copper mine was discovered at what is now Timișoara in 1848 during a tour organized for Queen Victoria in the Romanian Monarchean principality. Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these were typically printed right to left over more than one line on a page. For example, in Chinese typewriters, the comma is placed between the numeral 2 and the decimal point on paper, the decimal point is placed on the second line, and the decimal point on the fourth line. The Chinese are therefore accustomed to reading the text on paper starting from the right. (In this respect, the comma is analogous to ‘\’ in a text file.) Note that the right edge of the paper in a typewriter is almost always offset so that the last character printed will always be in the leftmost position. A standard page of typewritten text would therefore look something like:

12345678901234567890

Commas are therefore printed on the top line, ‘2’ on the next line

If you are eating later in the evening, the cephalic phase occurs during sleep. During digestion the stomach breaks down and processes the food and sends it through the esophagus where the esophagus turns into the duodenum and intestines to be absorbed.

Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current through electrical contacts called collectors on the front.

The current collection system consisted of three pairs of collectors (one pair for each street wire section) of three main components as shown above. These were fixed to the roadway and the tram line in a U-shaped pattern. The central contact point was called the shunt point.

In the early history of railway systems, a third rail was the most economical way of providing power to the trains. In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the technical flaws, the phonautograph was a commercial success, selling for $2000 when it was first introduced to the public.

The phonautograph was a highly technological experiment in sonics, so it is no surprise that the phonautograph was an exciting field of study. For the first time in history, it was possible to simultaneously capture live sounds and create a permanent record.

The phonautograph had great potential to tell us more about the human voice. There were two major applications. The first was to assist with the education of children. As an electronic device, the phonautograph could be introduced gradually to children of all ages, helping them learn about the voice. It would also give them a permanent record of the sound they heard, which many educators believed would help them to remember what they heard.

Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion; he defeated Russia on several occasions and in December 1807, having invaded southern Ukraine, he defeated the Russian army at Austerlitz, capturing much of his enemy's army.

The Treaty of Tilsit (7 July 1807) recognised Napoleon as first consul of France for life and Russia as first consul of the Confederation of the Rhine for life. It provided that the two countries would co-operate against British naval power, share control of Poland and co-operate on other matters such as trade. This Treaty was the first in a series of agreements with the Russian Empire that Napoleon would come to terms on as First Consul of France. The treaty also marked a period of renewed rivalry between Napoleon and the new King George III of the United Kingdom; this culminated in the Invasion of the Walcheren Islands

Energy in biology

The three major forms of energy, namely, chemical energy, electromagnetic energy and thermal energy are described in this article; along with a review of how they impact biology.

Thermal energy

In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaism to Islam, Christianity and Judaism. They also allowed Iranian people to practice other religious beliefs as well. After they were done with Iran (which they called Khorasan, and renamed it after their second Prophet Muhammad), they decided to move north, conquering North Europe and North Africa. At that point we refer to as the Arab people.

One of their first conquests was of North Africa, which you know today as Morocco. The first and second emperors of Morocco were Muhammad Bin Hassan and Abu Yusuf Yaqub al-Mansur. The second empress was Fatima al-Fihri, the wife of Yahya Al-Mansur and grandmother of Ahmad al-Mansur, and the mother-in-law and grandmother of Mohammed. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by a particular style, based on the iconography and iconography of a well-defined scriptural and liturgical tradition and on particular themes and traditions, in particular a close relationship between the image (as a kind of sacred text) and the painted text. Other traditions had more to offer. Thus there were a variety of different types of sculpture in all media: ivory, stone, metal and clay, but all reflecting specific conventions, which often followed those of painting but were not confined to it. The range of forms was wide, from relief and intaglio sculpture through various types of stone carving, stucco and relief carving in wood and metal, to bronze, ivory, and coloured glass. The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy under the French, through the establishment of a republican government on 25 July 1791. However, this autonomous status was only nominal; the colony was still subject to the authority of the French National Assembly and French law in its own sphere, as was common for French colonies. The political status of the colony was further eroded after the British occupied Saint-Domingue in 1793. In the aftermath, French authorities attempted to increase their control over the colony by creating two new, separate civil lists instead of one, establishing a 'national' assembly to represent the interests of the native black population, and attempting to increase the autonomy of the 'national' government. Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have a specific form of hardware architecture. It later came out the requirement of a specific form of hardware wasn't set in stone, however. Instead, this particular hardware platform is being named as "Metro". Metro refers to a family of unified design language that unifies both mobile and desktop interface. Metro's goal is to increase the "fluidity" of application windows between a desktop view and a small-screen view.

The Metro style includes a number of design elements, from the addition of an Aero-style interface to the addition of the "Live Tiles" which are designed to be used to perform tasks right from the desktop view. A new start button is also included, which gives the user a more fluid view of the operating system instead of having different menus to open each function and application.

By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). The Marathas were skilled in battle, having their own forces of light, cavalry and artillery as well as strong infantry forces led by the commander-in-chief, called Raja. During their reign, the Maratha Empire expanded and ruled over most of south India. Although a small portion of Madurai, one of their southern provinces, remained under the control of the Cholas and Pandiya dynasty (1350–1550 CE), the Marathas were the undisputed power in the region for several hundred years.

When the Mughals (1526–1788) conquered all of northern India, they also invaded the Maratha lands and annexed them. From then onward, the Marathas were a subjugated people, living under Mughal authority. After the death of Aurangzeb, they briefly regained their

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the island, which is the second largest in the Atlantic Ocean after the Bahamas, is the result of erosion from the last of the ancient volcanos), and an abundance of shallow and deep water. The highest point is Mont Hengist, located 1.5 km (0.975 mi) north of which is the main town.

The island was named in honour of Saint Helena, who was a fourth-century martyr. The original island, however, was named "Isle of Beauty" when it was discovered in 1415; to become the larger island of Saint Helena. After Henry, King of England, made two unsuccessful attempts to invade England's rebellious cousin, Princess Elizabeth, in the 17th century, he sold the island to a group of English merchants. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a ball on to a playing surface. The asymmetry has to do with the difference in the times at which the ball strikes the two sides of the surface. It is not the case that one side is always the cause and the other the effect. The two sides are simply different because of the way that time passes. In other words, the law of nonreciprocal causality does not apply to human behavior, but only to physical objects, and this is not a problem as it is a trivial consequence of the theory of time being absolute. Note that this would not apply to the case of a single cell, as cells are not macroscopic.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between him and the cardinals of the Curia, and to isolate the pope from the Curia in order to block Innocent's policy of reforming the Curia and his reform project for papal elections by means of new cardinals. John had Innocent's personal secretary arrested and confined in a dungeon. Eventually, the interdict ended. On December 8, Innocent VII named ten theologians to review all of the documents related to the case. This was largely a public relations move to repair John's damaged personal reputation. John himself responded by writing to the theologians, "I do not see why you should spend so much time on things that concern my conscience."

Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the belief that “reason and morality are the source of all religious belief” (Paine, [1805] 1955) without God. This idea that the world had been set up by a creator led to the idea that the universe itself had been created out of nothing. There is now no evidence that the universe does not have a beginning, and many people believe it would be impossible to set up such a system without a “first cause” from which everything else in the universe came from. The first cause itself is no harder to imagine than the God of theists, but theists believe that the divine, like God, is a necessary being, and that the first cause therefore cannot have existed before God, because the divine or God must have first existed. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.3 mph) with gusts at times), cloudiest (5 km in high overcast, with low clouds dropping to 500 m and above on some days), most bitterly cold (high season December to May), and rainy (7,000 mm annually). Because of the weather, St. John's is often perceived as being the gateway to the Maritimes.

From the perspective of a newcomer to Canada, St. John's is more exciting than Halifax, Nova Scotia, due to its numerous bars, clubs, and restaurants. The city also has many outdoor recreational activities, including a world-class sailing harbour and parks. Within St. John's, attractions include the Citadel, Harbour Park and Confederation House in Signal Hill and Humber College in Mount Pearl. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. An author described the period as the "golden years" of Notre Dame because it coincided with the nation's first postwar recession.

Background

Notre Dame College opened in 1842 in the "old" cathedral with an enrollment of 45 students during the first two years. The high point of the school's history was the 1879 football game against archrival University of Michigan, which at the time held the then-national collegiate championship title. At halftime, the referees made the controversial decision to call off play because the Irish had run out of time and needed to go back to their homes to prepare for the final exam. A student riot on the South Quad followed, and the Fighting Irish were denied their victory. In 1893 the new Notre Dame Stadium was dedicated.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas or regions. The Alps consist of three ranges of mountains (the Eastern Alps, the Savoy-Simmenthal Alps, and the Central Alps). These are the highest mountains in Switzerland as well as the longest and steepest chain of mountains on Earth. The Jura mountains extend north and northwest toward France and Germany. Lake Geneva lies in the eastern part of the country.

The Alps have an average height of. The highest point in Switzerland is Piz Bernina in the Swiss Alps (3,764 m), the highest mountain outside of Asia and nearby Mount Everest. Lake Lucerne, with an area of 50 000 km2 is the largest lake in Switzerland and the sixth or seventh among all the lakes in Europe.

Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm from the Köppen-Geiger climate classification, the climate is classified as a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfb), with cold, dry and windy winters, and mild to warm summers.

It has more than 150 days of precipitation a year, nearly all occurring in the warm season months of spring and autumn. Boston has distinct seasonal cycles that are a result of its maritime climate, with winter months having colder average temperatures and drier conditions, and spring and fall months being windier and warmer. Temperature extremes are more prevalent in winter than spring, and summers are mild by northern New England standards.

The video is a call to action for the "business community and all of us with a stake in how our economy is run", demanding that the President release a budget proposal that contains revenue-neutral tax and spending reforms, and that the debt ceiling be increased so the government can continue to pay its bills.

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that waqf was a fiscally responsible investment had taken hold, and even where it was not legal tender, it was commonly accepted. But in the late fourteenth century, many scholars came to reject the concept of waqf, primarily because they believed that God's rule over His creation should come before that of humankind, and a man's worldly dominion should not exceed God's. They argued that waqf property was under the control of the community; that was its legal status, period. They believed that under no circumstance should a man have absolute power over another man's property (even if the man was Muslim) and that this idea contradicted the core Islamic belief of a just distribution of wealth. Japan: The event was held in Nagano, which hosted the 1998 Winter Olympics, on April 26. Japanese Buddhist temple Zenkō-ji, which played host to the ceremony, received its first UNESCO Asia-Pacific Heritage Award in 2012.

Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the eyes of nocturnal moths can recognize various types of infrared light that humans cannot see.[1] An insect's eye organ can also detect and use directional vibrations as well as polarized light to orient a moth towards certain parts of an object like a light bulb or a flower.[2] An insect's eyes can also detect the presence of visible light even with poor visibility.[3][4]

It is believed that insects evolved their vision via the gradual process of co-evolution with their environment. When early insects were blind they could easily become preyed upon by arthropod hunters with more sophisticated vision, which led to the development of greater eyes.

Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem - its buildings are part of the compound called Supreme Court Building.

The Supreme Court is made up of seven judges, six of them men and one woman. A Judge of the Supreme Court is the second highest position in the system of courts within Israel. He is a judge appointed by the Prime Minister. He can be appointed on nomination only, if this nomination is accepted by approval of Shirei Tzedek.

Israeli Supreme Court judges are not subject to the control of the Knesset or any other legislative institution which may be controlled by political parties. The Supreme Court is therefore an independent institution. Its judgments are considered to be final; even a new decision handed down by a higher court cannot revoke a judgment by the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court is considered the highest court, despite being subordinate to the High Court of Justice

As the famous Oxford history professor Peter Laslett has argued, the twelfth and thirteenth centuries were "the age of the Renaissance."

Romantic relationships tend to increase in prevalence throughout adolescence. By age 15, 53% of adolescents have had a romantic relationship that lasted at least one month (Abrams and Wiederman 1995). During the same period, adolescents who engage in a romantic relationship are approximately 2.6 times more likely to smoke than their peers not involved in dating (Abrams et al. 1999). They are also more likely to use alcohol and drugs (Abrams et al. 2004). During the transition to adulthood, the risks associated with relationships increase (Abrams and Wiederman 1995) and are more evident in females. For example, a review of 25 years of retrospective research indicated that, starting at age 14, women were more likely than men in romantic relationships to report drug and alcohol use (Hakka et al. 1998), and they tended to report more relationship stressors and be in a relationship longer (Hakka et al. 1997). A predator's effect on its prey species is hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it can be used to make inferences about the relative fitness of the target species. The fitness effects of predators can therefore provide information about when to remove predators from the ecosystem to prevent adverse long-term ecological outcomes. In this study, we examined the fitness effects of different sized predators on the common garden crab, Homarus americanus. To date, research on predator-prey interactions has largely been limited to single or small populations and focused on specific predator populations which have little, if any, influence over other communities. The fitness effects of predators were tested in an entire ecosystem, the St. Clair River Estuary, on the St. Clair River, a large river in the Midwest. The St. Clair River is a multi-species predator-prey community with over 40 different species of fish, amphibian, bird, and several invertebrate

The other usage refers to a language that is socially subordinated to a regional or national standard language, often historically cognate or related to the standard language, which is referred to as the base language. The term may be considered to have originated with linguists of the 19th century who differentiated it from "idiom" (which is often used synonymously with "local language"), and from the now defunct practice of "subsidiary" languages or dialects, as the first two decades of the 20th century saw the increasing recognition of the importance of minority language education based on such a distinction. The most important languages within this term are Mandarin Chinese, Spanish, English, and Portuguese. However, the term is often used to describe languages which are not primarily part of a minority, though such languages may be used by a smaller ethnic group. A notable example is the local language of Taman Shud, an island in the Taman River on Java, Indonesia.

The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of northwest Pakistan and northwest Punjab.  The Thar and nearby deserts are inhabited by millions of migratory birds each winter. These areas are also well known for many plant life varieties and medicinal herbs.

However, since the end of the 1990s, a shift has taken place. A shift back to the "poststructuralist and postmodernist" traditions of Raymond Williams and Michel Foucault. This shift suggests that there is nothing inherently progressive about the liberal-pluralist traditions, they are not "radical" enough. Furthermore, as Foucault noted with his claim that "truth is not absolute," truth is contingent. When people find it convenient to have an absolute truth about the world, they take on moral claims and ideas about the nature of truth. These are not true, and "to say that a claim is true is not to say that it is more truthful."

Franklin S. Harris was appointed the university's president in 1921. He was the first BYU president to have a doctoral degree. Economists Hendrik Wolff, Howard Chong and Maximilian Auffhammer discuss the HDI from the perspective of data error in the underlying health metrics of the Index itself.

Hendrik Wolff, Director of Socio-economic Science at DIW in Berlin, and Maximilian Auffhammer, Director of the Centre for European Economic Research in Zürich, argue that the global development agenda suffers from poor data quality, rather than from lack of data.

The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender currently coached by Bill Self. The Jayhawks are the 12th all-time NCAA champions and have made the NCAA Final Four four times. Kansas has made a Final Four appearance in 12 consecutive seasons, while the Kansas City area has a long standing affinity for Jayhawks basketball.

The Jayhawks have an NCAA-record 8 Final Four appearances in the past 9 seasons. The Jayhawks have been among the nation's preeminent basketball programs for more than a century. KU is coached by Bill Self. He is one of four coaches to win NCAA basketball championships at two different schools, Kansas (1988) and Indiana (2003). The Jayhawks have won 3 Big 12 Conference titles (1987, 2017, 2018), 6 conference tournament titles (1975, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1991, 2002), and 2 conference regular season titles (1987, 1988). With the help of Charles Stearn, an expert on vacuum pumps, in 1878, Swan developed a method of processing that avoided the early bulbous shape of the earlier designs. That changed the way in which people viewed the Swan as it eventually became a popular design. The Swan is considered the first vacuum pump that used a centrifugal design. The pump operates by forcing air or gas out of a small chamber through a small hole and then to the outside. The high speed of the pump created the vacuum that then causes the air to be pulled out. This allows the pump to create a vacuum in a space such as a tube that then can be attached to a boiler. The Swan was produced from 1878 to about 1890. It was a great invention and became famous worldwide.

The next generation of vacuum pumps came in the form of centrifugal vacuum pumps. The Swan pump was used mostly for steam heating systems in homes and places such as hospitals which was quite common in 19th century

The morning after the election, the major candidates were neck and neck. It was clear that the result in Ohio, along with two other states who had not yet been counted, would be a deal-breaker. And when a few hundred votes were tallied, it was clear that Obama had won in Ohio. No matter what Obama does about the election, the electoral college and the way the states have chosen to count their votes in past presidential elections, the fact is it is very likely that Mitt Romney wins this election.

A 2010 study by Bray et al., using SNP microarray techniques and linkage analysis found that when assuming Druze and Palestinian Arab populations to represent the reference populations, the overall allele frequency of one SNP among Palestinians, a second SNP among Palestinians, and a third among Druze was 0.33, 0.55, and 0.45, respectively; yet a fourth SNP among Druze had an allele frequency of 0.25 [@pgen.1004228-Bray1]. The latter is equivalent to the estimated population frequency of the haplotype for this SNP, Hap6. The lack of the Hap6 haplotype among the Palestinian Arabs, but its high population frequency among the Druze, would provide a natural explanation for the difference in the haplotype frequency among the Druze vs. Palestinian Arab populations. We observe a similar trend for the other SNP under study ([Figure 5](#pgen-1004228-g005){ref-type="fig"}).

Kurita passed through San Bernardino Strait at 03:00 on 25 October and headed along the coast of Samar. The only thing standing in his path was Typhoon Krosa, which killed about 500 sailors and fishermen from Samar. Kurita continued along the coast of Samar under the command of Vice Admiral Kajioka, which was ordered by Vice Chief of the Naval Staff Maresuke Kishi, who told Kurita to destroy the Philippine forces on Mindanao in coordination with the land forces. Kurita's fleet reached Lingayen Gulf on 26 October, and on the following day Krosa reached Samar, where its gusts destroyed many of the shipping there.

On 29 October, Vice Admiral Kajioka, whose squadron consisted of 11 warships including Kurita's flagship, took up battle stations around the Lingayen Gulf. Kajioka then received instructions to proceed north to Manila Bay.

Nanjing ( listen; Chinese: 南京, "Southern Capital") is the city situated in the heartland of lower Yangtze River in Jiangsu province, in the eastern China. Historically there was a close union of people and a prosperous community, when they developed the culture and civilization more than a thousand years ago. Even now the city still maintains the ancient and cultural tradition.

History

In the 1st century, Nanjing was also named Shu (書), as it was the capital of the Shu country in the ancient Chinese history book. The Shu country was one of the Eight Banners, under the feudal dynastic system of imperial China. The history starts from the Warring States period and ends with the end of the Ming dynasty in 1644.

The founding members of the Nanjing city came in the time of Qin dynasty and were known as the Wuhui (乌會兒潘氏).

Israel has a school life expectancy of 15.5 years and a literacy rate of 97.1% according to the United Nations. The State Education Law regulates the curriculum, the schools, the school teachers and the school administrators.

The Israel Education Ministry has defined a school as a place where children study, live and are under supervision. Some schools are in cities, but many operate as boarding schools in rural areas for young Jewish children or in Arab localities for both Jews and Arabs. The educational system is comprehensive, covering all aspects of child life, beginning with children before their first birthday, which is at the preschool level, progressing through elementary, middle and high school grades, where learning skills and the core subjects are covered, and culminating at the university level.
